Introduction

Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome (BWS) is an imprinting disorder characterized by overgrowth and an increased risk for embryonal tumors.  BWS is associated with genetic or epigenetic modifications affecting chromosome 11p15.5.  BWS classically presents with macrosomia, macroglossia, and omphalocele.

Pathogenesis



BWS results from dysregulated imprinting at the chromosome 11p15.5 locus.  Normally, both paternally and maternally inherited alleles of a gene are expressed.  However, only certain genes are imprinted, which involves a series of epigenetic modifications that prevent expression of the paternally or maternally inherited allele (

figure 1
).  Therefore, imprinted genes are expressed monoallelically.  Imprinting is a highly regulated process, and, in cases of BWS, dysregulated imprinting alters the expression of certain genes involved in cell growth and proliferation.  Specifically, the chromosome 11p15.5 locus contains:



  • Imprinting control region 1 (ICR1):  Regulates the expression of insulin-like growth factor 2 (IGF2), a growth-promoting gene, and H19, a tumor suppressor gene.
  • Imprinting control region 2 (ICR2):  Regulates the expression of CDKN1C, a gene that inhibits cell proliferation.


Various mechanisms of dysregulation can lead to the BWS phenotype, including:



  • Loss of methylation at ICR2 (50% of cases):  Results in overexpression of IGF2 and somatic overgrowth.
  • Paternal uniparental disomy of chromosome 11 (20% of cases):  Results in 2 paternally inherited chromosomes, overexpression of IGF2, and somatic overgrowth.
  • Gain of methylation at ICR1:  Results in loss of H19 tumor suppression, as well as overexpression of IGF2 and somatic overgrowth.
  • Mutations in CDKN1C:  Result in loss of inhibition of cell proliferation and somatic overgrowth.


Risk factors include advanced maternal age, use of assisted reproductive technology, and family history of BWS, especially in cases of CDKN1C mutations.

Clinical presentation



The clinical presentation of BWS is highly variable.  Classically, BWS presents in infancy with (

figure 2
):



  • Macrosomia.
  • Macroglossia.
  • Omphalocele/umbilical hernia.
  • Hemihyperplasia.


Other clinical features include:



  • Ear abnormalities (eg, anterior creases, posterior pits).
  • Visceromegaly involving the liver, spleen, kidneys, adrenal glands, and/or pancreas.
  • Vascular malformations (eg, nevus flammeus).
  • Midface hypoplasia.
  • Infraorbital creases.
  • Undescended testes.
  • Embryonal tumors (eg, Wilms tumor [nephroblastoma], hepatoblastoma) in childhood.
  • Renal anomalies (eg, medullary dysplasia, duplicate collecting systems, nephrolithiasis).


Macrosomia and polyhydramnios are the most common features detected prenatally.  In addition, approximately one-third of fetuses with isolated omphalocele on prenatal ultrasonography are diagnosed with BWS.  Other congenital anomalies (eg, macroglossia, visceromegaly) may be detected later in pregnancy.

Diagnosis



Confirmatory genetic testing should be performed in all suspected cases of BWS, regardless of the phenotype severity, due to the increased risk for embryonal tumors, which require close surveillance.  The clinical presentation of BWS is highly variable, and patients may be diagnosed at any age.  Following the initial diagnosis, further evaluation may be required, depending on the patient's clinical features, as follows:



  • Macroglossia:  Requires assessment for airway obstruction and feeding difficulties.
  • Visceromegaly:  Requires abdominal ultrasonography to evaluate the size, structure, and position of the abdominal organs.  In older patients, a CT scan or MRI of the abdomen may be considered to screen for tumors.
  • Renal disease:  Requires renal ultrasonography to evaluate the size, structure, and position of the kidneys.


Neonatal hypoglycemia is common in BWS, but patients can develop hypoglycemia at any age.

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis for BWS is broad, reflecting the wide spectrum of BWS phenotypes, and includes other causes of macrosomia, macroglossia, and hypoglycemia, such as:



  • Sotos syndrome (5q35 microdeletion syndrome):  A disorder characterized by macrosomia, macrocephaly, characteristic facial features (eg, bossed forehead, hypertelorism), developmental delay, and intellectual disability.
  • Simpson-Golabi-Behmel syndrome:  An X-linked genetic disorder characterized by macrosomia, visceromegaly, coarse facies, polydactyly, and congenital heart disease.
  • Perlman syndrome:  An autosomal recessive disorder characterized by macrosomia, visceromegaly, characteristic facial features (eg, depressed nasal bridge, micrognathia), and intellectual disability.
  • Idiopathic hemihyperplasia (ie, no syndromic features).


Each of these diagnoses is also associated with an increased risk for Wilms tumor.

Management



Management of BWS involves a multidisciplinary approach and depends on the clinical features at the time of diagnosis.  In addition to medical (eg, specialized nipples for macroglossia) and surgical (eg, omphalocele repair) interventions required for congenital anomalies, management involves close surveillance for the following:



  • Hypoglycemia:  Occurs most commonly in the neonatal period but can occur later in life.  Patients should be screened for neonatal hypoglycemia, and parents should be educated about the signs and symptoms of hypoglycemia in preparation for discharge.  If untreated, hypoglycemia can lead to developmental delay.
  • Embryonal tumors:  The exact screening protocol may vary but generally includes serial abdominal and renal ultrasonography (including the adrenal glands).  In addition, elevated serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is associated with hepatoblastoma, and serial measurements are recommended for screening.  Serial chest radiographs and urinary homovanillic acid and vanillylmandelic acid measurements may be considered for neuroblastoma screening; however, false-positive results are common.  Close surveillance is indicated through age 7 and as needed for suspected malignancy.
  • Nephrocalcinosis/nephrolithiasis:  These conditions require serial renal ultrasonographic tests beyond surveillance for embryonal tumors (ie, age 7).  Serial urine calcium/creatinine ratios may identify patients with mild renal disease and normal renal ultrasonography.
  • Leg-length discrepancy:  Leg-length discrepancy requires serial measurements and referral to orthopedics for management (eg, closure of growth plates of the longer leg).


Because of the increased risk for embryonal tumors in patients with mild phenotypes, close surveillance is required for all patients, regardless of phenotype severity.  Management also involves genetic counseling regarding the risk for recurrence in future pregnancies.

Prognosis



The prognosis of BWS is generally favorable, especially with prompt diagnosis and management of embryonal tumors.  However, complications of premature birth, macroglossia, and hypoglycemia can also increase the risk for mortality.  Developmental delay can occur in cases involving certain genetic mutations, untreated neonatal hypoglycemia, and premature birth.  Although most patients experience rapid growth in childhood, the rate of growth decreases by age 7-8.

Summary
